Are more granular measures of Ag activity related to lake water quality across hundreds of lakes and their watersheds?

## Results - TN Model

Specific regions have markedly different spatial random effect slopes.

  \begin{figure}
    \includegraphics[height=4.0cm]{../../JournalSubmissions/lagos_ag/figures/tn_summary-1.png}\hspace{3em}\includegraphics[height=4.0cm]{../../JournalSubmissions/lagos_ag/figures/tn_re-1.png}
  \end{figure}
  
## Results - TN Model

Lake TN in highlighted regions are more sensitive to Ag cover relative to other regions.

Lower TP in the highlighted regions may indicate P limitation.
  
  \begin{figure}
    \includegraphics[width=5.5cm]{../../JournalSubmissions/lagos_ag/figures/tn_re_hu4-1.png}\includegraphics[width=5.5cm]{../../JournalSubmissions/lagos_ag/figures/tn_re_compare-1.png}
  \end{figure}

## Conclusions

Lake TP not strongly related to granualar measures of Ag activity. 

Lake TN strongly related to granular measures of Ag activity such as buffer composition, fertilizer inputs, and corn cover. 

Lake TN sensitivity to Ag activity may be a function of stoichiometric P limitation.
